When I first encountered CodeWiki, I briefly considered becoming angry. But I got
over it. CodeWiki does not deserve my anger, and I won't waste my breath trying
to blow it down. It is so bumbling, so helpless, so naïvely constructed, that I
am sure it will soon fall over of its own accord. If CodeWiki were only an
intern's vibe-coded hackathon project, I would give it a pat on the head, and
be content that I had done my charitable deed for the day. But since it is not
only an intern's vibe-coded hackathon project, but a product released by a
four-trillion-dollar company, I feel a need to warn my fellow engineers about
it, lest they doubt their own senses when a thing with four trillion dollars
behind it begins gaslighting them about their own codebase.

You should not trust CodeWiki. You should not rely on CodeWiki. You should not
use CodeWiki, unless you are a masochist, or enjoy cringe comedy.

For those who have not yet had the pleasure: CodeWiki is a website consisting
entirely of AI-generated documentation for open-source projects. It is,
notably, _not_ a wiki. A wiki, as defined by Ward Cunningham, is a website
editable by its users, and there are no human editors on CodeWiki. This
oversight, — or misunderstanding, however you want to diagnose it — is one of
my reasons for thinking that CodeWiki is the product of an intern — because
only someone very young, or very new to the software industry, could have
stumbled into a professional situation without knowing what a wiki is.

In fact, as far as I can tell, there are exactly two ways that humans can input
information of any kind into CodeWiki. I have tried both of them. The first
input lets you search for the documentation associated
with an open source project, or, if the documentation doesn't exist, request
that it be generated. The second input is a chat sidebar where you can ask
Google's AI, Gemini, questions about the code — or maybe only about the
documentation; it isn't clear which.

I requested documentation for [Khan Academy's Perseus] — a codebase with which
I am deeply familiar, having worked on it daily for more than two years.
Perseus, which powers Khan Academy's practice exercises, is about a million
lines of TypeScript, sparsely commented but reasonably organized, tested, and
type-annotated, and absolutely wormy with historical context. It is legacy code
in the finest sense, and as it lacks a comprehensive human-written manual, I
thought it might plausibly benefit from an AI generated one.

So! Let's see how the AI did, shall we?

As a reminder: I cannot be accused of "using it wrong" or "being bad at
prompting" because _Google wrote all the prompts for this, and trained the
language model they're fed into; literally the only thing I did was search for
my project's GitHub repo._

## What CodeWiki thought of Perseus

This is the very first thing in the generated documentation: a boxes-and-arrows
diagram which ostensibly describes the project's architecture.

![a boxes and arrows diagram of some bullshit](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

As I said, I have worked on Perseus for two years, and before today considered
myself pretty well acquainted with its major parts and how they are organized
— but that diagram proves I was overconfident. I would never have been able to
produce it out of my own head — not in a million years.

_What_ do those arrows represent? They can't represent dependency; by design,
`Data & Schema Foundation` does not depend on anything else — certainly not
`Content Authoring and QA`. Do the arrows represent dataflow? Apparently not,
because then `AI Integration API` should not have an arrow pointing to `Perseus
Core Renderer`. Perhaps they mean... but it's no good guessing; let's ask the
AI.

> ME:<br>
> in the first diagram, what do the arrows represent?
>
> GEMINI:<br>
> I am sorry, but your question appears to be about a diagram, and the Khan/Perseus repository documentation does not contain diagrams.
>
> ME:<br>
> I mean the first diagram in the generated documentation
>
> GEMINI:<br>
> In the generated documentation, specifically in the story files for renderers like ArticleRenderer and HintsRenderer (e.g., packages/perseus/src/__docs__/article-renderer.stories.tsx and packages/perseus/src/__docs__/hints-renderer.stories.tsx), the diagrams are visual representations of Perseus content rendered within Storybook.
>
> For example, packages/perseus/src/__docs__/article-renderer.stories.tsx shows ArticleRendererWithDebugUI rendering various article structures, and packages/perseus/src/__docs__/hints-renderer.stories.tsx shows HintsRenderer displaying different hint types, including interactive graphs. 

It does nothing of the kind; there are no "diagrams" in those files. In any
case, Gemini continues:

> More specifically, for elements within an "interaction" widget, the arrows can represent axes on a graph. For instance, in the file packages/perseus/src/widgets/interactive-graphs/backgrounds/axis-arrows.tsx, the AxisArrows component renders arrowheads on the x and y axes of a graph. These arrows indicate the positive and negative directions of the axes. [...]

Gemini apparently can't see the generated documentation at all, but won't admit it.
Did Google forget to tell the chatbot that it was on a documentation website?

> ME:<br>
> no, I mean the generated documentation on CodeWiki
>
> GEMINI:<br>
> In the generated documentation on CodeWiki, specifically within the story files for interactive graph widgets, the arrows typically refer to axis arrows on a Cartesian coordinate system.

Now it's anchoring on its previous responses. I cleared the chat and started
over:

> ME:<br>
> in the first diagram in the Perseus documentation on CodeWiki, what do the arrows represent?
>
> GEMINI:<br>
> I apologize, but I cannot answer your question about the first diagram in the Perseus documentation on CodeWiki. The provided context does not include any diagrams or images, so I don't have information about what the arrows in such a diagram would represent.

I tried a few more things; the long and short of it is that the chatbot only seems to
have access to the original codebase, not the generated documentation. Ah, well.
The mystery of the arrows will have to remain unsolved.

Proceeding to the first paragraph:

> Khan Academy's Perseus rendering engine processes educational problems defined in a specific format, rendering interactive and static content for various contexts. It generates interactive elements such as mathematical input fields, multiple-choice questions, and graphical components within exercises and articles.

This is no improvement on the first paragraph of the codebase's own README.
The LLM could have escaped critique by simply repreducing that
paragraph verbatim:

> Perseus is Khan Academy's exercise system. This repo contains the code needed to take a problem in the Perseus format and present it, allow interaction, and grade the result of a learner's work.

But LLMs cannot pass up an opportunity to befungle and enflatulate the work of
their betters. This one has summarized Perseus's duties with the quaint phrase
"processes educational problems," which is notable both for its originality and
for the vague sense of unease it gives the reader. That unease is heightened by
the addendum "defined in a specific format," which, despite including the word
"specific," manages to be totally vague. The LLM then bludgeons the perfectly
sufficient word "content" with the gratuitous "interactive and static," and
completes the assassination by throwing in a "for various contexts" — just as a
precaution, I suppose, though I don't think the patient would have lived in any
case.

The LLM then claims that Perseus "generates interactive elements." I think that
accusation is overblown; Perseus has never _generated_ any elements, only
displayed them. But what does an LLM know about displaying? It can't even
display the text of a README in what is supposed to be documentation for an
open source repository.

Like all LLM-generated text, this only seems accurate if you read it with your
eyes blurred and your brain in idle. The AI has gotten hold of the correct noun
phrases and some of the correct verbs, but it has not assembled them correctly.

## Conclusion

LLM apologists may argue that CodeWiki is still in its infancy, and will
improve. But I have a less optimistic outlook.

- The flaws are not factual "mistakes"
- They are errors of omission, of inappropriate emphasis, haphazard organization,
  confusing association.
- These behaviors are intentionally trained in, not accidental.
